Cardiff Carnival 25th Anniversary Project, interviewer Steve Fletcher, interviewee Liz
Dutton, the venue Swicker Office and the date is Sunday the 16th of November 2015. Liz,
would you be kind enough to spell your name for us for the record?
Liz Dutton. Thank you much indeed. Can you tell us when and how did you first get involved or hear
about the Cardiff Carnival? Well in my work as a youth worker part of my role was to organize play
schemes and one year I decided that I didn't want to actually organize and run a play scheme that I
just wanted to be part of and just be a play worker. So during that time somebody mentioned
to me that there was carnival going on at Fitzhallen School so I was a bit curious so I went along to
see you know what was going on and basically you know didn't leave. So that would have been back in
the distant past 1991. Yeah. And I remember you saying that you remember what you did I mean you
were dancing on the day itself were you in a dance group? Yeah. What kind of costume did you have the very first time round?
Gosh it was I think the basis of it was the skirt was I think was purple I knew I know
there was a multi-colored sash there was a headdress and there were bobbles on shoes and things.
It was a tribute to indigenous people I seem to remember. I think that was it. Which indigenous people I couldn't tell you
not off the top of my head by frankly. And that very first time that you got involved
did your children get involved at that point or did you bring them on on board the carnival bus
No no they got involved at that point my daughter actually was in the dance group with me and she had a costume
and my son was more or less Stuart he got involved in like the Stuart because he didn't want to like
dress up in carnival costume. But he supported the carnival every year you know those people in the yellow bibs are absolutely vital to it.
Yeah most definitely but yeah my daughter was in the dance group same as me and she really enjoyed it that first time.
That's fantastic. So whenever I think of your role in carnival I always refer to you as a carnival queen
because you always wore to my mind except for this possibly this first year
you always wore a large backpack costume which meant that you know you were what can I say
brilliant to look at you know big big costumes. So how did that come about was it was it working with Amaru or?
Yes it was actually. You always seem to design a costume that was like really large
but with a backpack so yeah yeah yeah. With a backpack quite dynamic really. Yes. It was fun wearing them
yeah it was you know it was really. Did the design get was it ever too what was it like I mean you
you're having to rehearse in these things you're having to add to them you come the big day of the
big parade you know you can take an hour or two with getting ready and all the rest of it. How comfortable
were they or did it change over time? It did change over time I mean in the beginning they were a bit
uncomfortable and you know adjustments were always being made and stuff but you know over
a course of time the backpacks got lighter so they were easier to move around in and yes I see
it seems to me to think yeah eventually we found tubular steel and that's right a joy of foam rubber
yeah that's right yeah so I can remember the early ones seem to virtually cripple people and
slowly but surely we yeah as a group we improved in what we were doing definitely yeah but um
you know with the carnival it was the whole thing of on the day you know watching people's faces
especially the little children you know in awe of what they were seeing you know because it was so
colorful and dynamic and they'd want to come up and touch you and you know and that kind of thing
and you know that part of it you know it was it was really good it was and the build-up to it as
well you know the whole carnival camp um I mean my son and daughter I mean they they met so many
people and they've grown up with so many um people of their their own age and and yet they only used
to meet them once a year a carnival camp but it was like they'd spoken to them yesterday
do you know what I mean and they've made lifelong friends and not only that it enabled my children
as well to learn to work alongside adults you know to work alongside adults and not only that
to work alongside lots of different people because my son and daughter they're grown up now and they
can they can relate to anybody you know whether they're old young you know you know any background
any background at all any walk of life at all yes and you know carnival you know played a
part in that to be honest you know it did yeah without without a doubt but you must have a fairly
amazing skills base now I mean uh again when I think of you I think of you sticking stuff on and
certainly with a glue gun and not necessarily going ouch ouch ouch every time that uh yeah you

you also you mentioned you also did this in terms of some of the percussion and the rhythm and yeah
yes yeah um when I ran play schemes um I actually took the skills that I'd learned in carnival and
put them to use within the play schemes carnival theme every time I did a play scheme there was
always a carnival theme used to do tie-dye make headdresses I purchased instruments so they could
have a little percussion band and also um one year within my community um I organized
a carnival theme where Splot is the community I live in yeah and um we did a procession with
young people dressed up made costumes and doing percussion around Splot and that was part of um
Splot carnival uh it seemed to recall as well that um yeah obviously carnival the carnival camp ends
